title: id request, sans serif sample from the 30's - similar to Gill Sans Schoolbook {Yves}
content:
hello

anyone able to id this type? i've spotted this on several finnish architectural publications from around 1930-1950. (used in two different weights, haven't seen any italics.) i'd be surprised if it was of finnish origin. in that case there would be some secret typographic history i haven't been informed about.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [sans-sample.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20130820001526/http:/typophile.com/files/sans-sample.jpg) | 134.07 KB |
author: juhani

comments.content: It also looks like Vista Sans, if memory serves. And Fiendstar as well.
Except that Vista Sans was designed three years ago, not over half a century ago. ;^)
I said it "looks like" not "it is." Man, tough crowd. ;-)
Exactly. Both my thoughts are wrong. But check out that "y." I don't recall Gill Sans Schoolbook having that straight descender.

It could be Gill Sans Schoolbook with the 'y' from Gill Sans.

- Lex

_Man, tough crowd. ;-)_

Yeah, us type geeks, we even bite the heads off chickens too, just like Ozzy.

;-)

You have to realise this is a very competitive board, but I can assure you it is all in good humour. :^)

I hope you didn't misread my remark as arrogance, Michael. ;^)

thanks for all the answers.

gill sans schoolbook looks very much like it to me. only differences seem to be the "l" which is a straight line, the "4" (doesn't show in the sample) which is closed and the "y" as mentioned, all pointing to the regular gill sans.

the "M" has slanted vertical lines and the center touches the baseline, which doesn't happen in any gill sans version i managed to find.

linotype's gill sans infant looks pretty much identical to the gill sans schoolbook...? both versions appear to have a thicker stroke than in this printed sample.

is there a digital version of gill sans with a light cut with alternates for "a" and "g" as in schoolbook/infant? :)

vista sans looks too condensed. fiendstar is pretty nice, the light version has the weight right. don't like the "y" though.
juhani...did you ever find out what this is? I would like to know too
